111332.content:
The noises and screams sound female, females in dire need of help. However, the situation is none of your business. So of course you charge right in.
The door is shut as you approach. You hope it is a cheap one, or at least you can replace it with a cheap one. But either way, you are opening it the proper barbarian way, with your shoulder and at full speed.
The door quickly converts to "used" condition as you crash into the room and try to figure out what is going on. With at least a dozen screaming women, who have between them perhaps enough clothing for one of them [but which is way too much in your opinion] make it hard to focus, but the three men with swords and a none too friendly attitude seem worth attention.
"WHAT GO ON HERE? THROG NO LIKE!" Pretty much just an act. Granted you are not smart enough to make much of a wizard, but you are hardly stupid. Still, when people see the stereotype big stupid barbarian looking angry, they either run or they think some really stupid trick will get rid of you. Either way, the result is apt to be better for you than for them. Sometimes it is smart to be stupid.
The apparent leader of these three manages to do both tactics. "Beat it. This is none of..." His voice trails off as he realized just how far he is looking up when he tries to look you in the eye. "... I mean we are just here doing some redecorating, and the girls got a little upset at the changes. Isn't that right?" His glare at the ladies is presumably intended to intimidate them into silence.
You do not bother to see if it works. "THAT SILLY" you bellow and step forward with sword out. "YOU LEAVE NOW!"
"Well in that case..." the leader answers, and the three rogues attack.
Rather, two of them do. The one that was trying to sneak up behind you is busy trying to keep his guts from falling out after your sword slash takes care of him. But two rogues can still give a careless barbarian a really bad day if they flank you. You have some painful memories of that sort of misadventure. So you desperately move to keep them from getting that advantage.
Seeing the dispatching of their companion, the other two pause long enough to miss the best chance to get you. But they come on, even as you roar with rage. Not really too bright of them, but it's not too hard to hurt an angry barbarian, and their swords make some nasty cuts into you.
Unfortunately for them, a raging barbarian takes a lot of killing. You are just annoyed by the wounds. Really really annoyed, but not slowed down as you cut the head off one of them. The leader is rather shocked to find himself alone, but has the courage, or the stupidity, to attack you again. That hurts him a lot more than it hurts you. Your sword goes all the way thru him.
As you tug your sword loose, you look for new foes and are disappointed to see none. You calm down, and once again experience the disadvantage of being a raging barbarian. Without your anger to strengthen you, you feel weak and helpless. Those pinprick wounds are suddenly firestorms of pain. You are barely able to stand and stagger over to a couch and more fall onto it than sit down.
For a moment, the women stand in shock. Then they rush to your side to deal with your wounds. One seems to be some sort of cleric, and you are soon able to stand.
As you thank the ladies of the evening, the madam steps forward and tells you. "You have saved my life and I pay my debts. My darlings are all slaves, so you may have your choice as a gift if you promise to treat her well. Alternately, you may become my business partner. I warn you that will be dangerous. I have enemies you will have to deal with. You should get more that way, but you will earn it."
"Well, I guess I will ..."

1113321.content:
"..be your partner." you announce. "I no run from danger."
You pause to look around at the girls, some of which are close enough to give you a very good view. "Me partner? That mean I own part of each girl?"
"Yes and no." the madam responds. "I don't suppose the ladies will often refuse you, but you will have to get their permission."
"But they slaves..."
"Quite valuable slaves. They make me a lot of gold as long as they work hard, and unhappy slaves don't work hard or well. We have got to keep the girls happy, and that means you stay off them unless they want you on."
"But..." Not that you are sure that you would want a lass who didn't want you, but...
"No! You are just going to have to say 'Please'." She confirms. "I doubt they will say no all that often to a stud who has maybe saved their lives, but you are going to have to take their word on the subject."
With a sigh, you switch subjects. "OK, now what trouble?
"Gilles is the main problem." The madam explains. "He's a new crime lord in the area, and he is being greedy. That was his thugs you just killed."
"He only killed one. I was able to save the other two." Looking up, you see the cleric-prostitute who healed you is smiling happily, and two of the thugs are getting back to their feet, still badly wounded, but clearly alive despite the massive wounds you gave them.
"Peace!" the madam groans. "What are you doing? They would have raped and killed you."
"But they would have died, Lady Tabra." Peace answers as if that explains why she should save the lives of vicious slime. You wonder if she is simple-minded, but clerics are usually pretty smart...
Tabra seems to agree with you that there is something weird about Peace's mental processes, but apparently she has had this argument before. Instead she rolls her eyes to the ceiling and turns to the two thugs. "Wigan! Take your two louts and get out! You have your answer."
Wigan seems willing to argue, until you get to your feet and pull out your sword. Then the two pick up the body of the third and stumble out. "This isn't over." he warns as he leaves.
"All right girls," Tabra orders. "We have got to clean up this mess. Let's get to work." It quickly becomes apparent that "We" includes you, particularly for the heavy items. At least the women are quick with compliments about your strength, and how impressed they are with you. You also get to "accidentally" bump into the girls, who make no objections, and some of which bump back. One does so quite vigorous, and earns a rebuke from Tabra, "Barbara! Business before pleasure. Do the housework now, and save your eagerness for the Johns tonight." Barbara sticks out her tongue at Tabra, but moves away from you, tho not without an enticing wiggle. [Not that you get much chance to admire it. Tabra has a couch that needs moving.]
Finally the place looks like a brothel, and not the scene of a battle. Tabra announces "Good. Now get yourselves cleaned up. I don't know if we are going to have a great or dead night, but we need to be ready. So put on your best."
As the girls head upstairs, Tabra turns to you. Clearly the two of you need to discuss some things. Who is this Gilles? And just what is he likely to try? Just what percentage of the business do you own? And what are you to do to earn that share? And...
1113321.title: you become a partner

11133211.content:
You ask Tabra "Who this Gilles?"
"He's the current crimelord in this area." Tabra answers. "A business like this is nearly always paying off somebody, actually several somebodies. And having this thug come around and demand money if we want to stay in business is par for the course. But Gilles is being greedy, and won't listen to reason.
"I'm not sure of the details. I just want these people to leave me alone to run my business. But from what I hear, Gilles convinced some of the more powerful thugs in his gang that merchants like me could be squeezed for a lot more gold. That's crazy. I can't pay what he demands and stay in business, and I doubt most of the others can either. But he managed to convince those other jerks, and so the lout who had been leading them -never thought I'd say I wish he was back- had an accident. The talk is that there were seven witnesses that say it was an accident, and seven knife holes in his back. I wasn't alone in ordering seven rounds of drinks for the house in celebration, until I found out about Gilles.
"I can't say, but talk is that some of the others don't like Gilles much, and if he can't come thru with the gold he promised, he's going to have his own accident. Can't be too soon for me. But right now he is really pushing for that gold, really hard, and he just won't believe I can't pay. He's talking about how he can get the others to buckle if he breaks me. I'd laugh at him if I wasn't going to be broke or dead before he finds out how wrong he is.
"So you are going to be earning your share of the business. I don't know what he is going to try, but killing you has got to be high on his to do list. He can't let you beat up three of his boys and let you walk the streets. You stay in town and he is coming after you.
"I'll give you a description of Gilles -he's a big fellow, tho hardly in your range- and those of his boys, tho I don't know most of them, at least not well enough that you should let random strangers get behind you.
"Gilles is going to do something to this place too. Just what I can only guess and worry about. You are going to have to be ready to stop it, whatever it is. Ainia will help you there."
"Ainia?" you ask.
"Here." you hear behind you. Turning, you see a tallish severe lass, dressed up like an amazon. [Well, an amazon with maybe about half as much armor as you would expect, but the sword is a decent one at least.] "I do a fair amount of the guard duty around here. We had a man too, but the coward took off when those three showed up.
"We can expect the city guard to watch part of the time," Tabra continues, "at least I will be paying them to. But at least one of you two had better be awake and ready at all times."
"I can help too." Turning again, your face ends up in a delightful set of breasts, with a redhead smiling down at you at her success in sneaking up behind you and standing on a chair to get the needed height. "I'm Evaine. I'm pretty talented at roguish tricks."
"If you were really talented, you would not be here." Tabra reproves.
"Well, it looked like an easy mark. And it would have been too if the others had done their part. But when things went South, I just got stuck holding the bag." Turning to you, Evaine continues, "Jerks wouldn't pay to break me out of jail, so I ended up being sold here, with the threat of losing a hand if I tried to escape. It's not so bad really, and I'm not going to let these louts push us around."
"Well, we have other matters to consider..." Tabra announces.
11133211.title: a briefing on the enemy and allies

111332111.content:
"...Our first Johns should arrive soon. You are to make yourself visible, and friendly, while looking dangerous."
"Sound confusing."
"Well, it shouldn't be too bad." Tabra answers. "As big as you are, just holding that big sword should take care of the threat department. But you have to remember that these are paying customers, and we defer to them as much as possible. At the same time, some of them will demand more than the girls want to give, and you have to keep the girls safe, preferably without making the John unhappy.
"Now you have to watch out for Gilles. I don't think he is going to try anything tonight, but we can't count on that. So keep your eyes open and look for ways he might try something."
Tabra likely has more to say, but now the girls start to enter the room. She pauses to inspect each lass, an inspection that seems distinctly personal to you. Of course, she does have to make sure the merchandise is in good shape, but even so... However, you are certainly not going to object since you also get a fine view, and if Tabra's hands seem to caress rather than inspect, you are happy with that.
However, now a man is approaching the door, and the girls rush to make him welcome. Looking behind him, you are surprised to realize the day is over and it's dark outside. It shouldn't be a surprise. You have been working for some time, and prostitutes are called ladies of the evening for a reason. Still, you had not noticed the time going by. [Spending the time surrounded by underclad lovelies likely has something to do with that.]
The fellow takes his time about making his choice, naturally since he is being mobbed by about a dozen lasses. But he eventually makes a selection, Barbara, and the two head up the stairs. He is not up there long, and returns looking happier, and presumably poorer. But by the time he does, other men are arriving.
For such a desirable location, the evening rapidly becomes surprisingly dull. Of course, now you are a worker instead of a patron. Later the girls may be fun for you, but right now they have to concentrate on the Johns, not you. And you have to concentrate on possible problems, which are not happening. [Well, technically a John does get a little loud, but when you approach and ask what the problem is, he wheels and looks you in the ...chest, and quiets right down. He still has a complaint, but it is one that Tabra has to deal with.]
A visit by some members of the city guard at least provides a little variety, but they prove just as routine. "We pay off the city guard as well as others." Tabra explains. "The good news is that they are generally satisfied with sex. The bad news is that they are lousy tippers."
"Tip?"
"Of course." Tabra answers. "A good John adds a bonus for the girl. And if she really works the Johns for tips, she can buy her freedom in maybe two years."
"But how slave buy self? You own." you protest. "Her gold your gold."
"Not if I want them to work hard." Tabra corrects. "If I just don't ask where the gold came from, I get a hard worker, and a lot of gold. So my girls are mostly saving up to buy their freedom.
"And these guardsmen will not pay me or my girls. But we need to stay on their good side. And at least they are not too greedy.
"Well, it's been a quiet, but reasonable night so far. Now we can just hope Gilles won't try anything, at least not yet."
111332111.title: the night's business

1113321111.content:
Prostitutes are called ladies of the evening for good reason, but there is a limit on how late they work. Light provided by fire is expensive, and so nearly everybody wakes at first light, which means not staying up late. There are some exceptions of course, but business at the brothel trails off well before the witching hour. The brothel is closed long before the 1st bell of the hour rings, much less the last, only marginally because of fear of that evil hour. Financially, it is just not worth the small amount of business.
But while the girls can now go to sleep, some of them alone, you can't. You are going to have to stand guard duty, at least until Gilles is dealt with. You would bet that Gilles will not try anything tonight. It sounds much better to you to scout you out first. Maybe see if a little bribe will cause you to switch sides or go away. Sounds much smarter than just his just barging into a situation he doesn't understand.
Of course, barging in was just what you did, and maybe Gilles does think like you do. That means you can't take a chance and take a nap. You have got to be ready just in case he does try something tonight.
Locks on all the doors and all windows shut and barred. Of course, Gilles has to have some talented fellows to get by them, but even talented fellows make noise at times. It's worth the effort.
Now a tour of the grounds. The first of many. You need to know all the ways attackers might come. You are also looking at how to eliminate hiding places and approaches. Again you don't expect to do as well as the foes can, but you can at least make their job harder.
Will he try to burn the place down? It seems unlikely. He won't get any gold from a business that no longer exists. Still, if he can scare all the other businesses... But it is not something he is apt to try before he has exhausted all means to get the gold. Well, you might as well look around while you can.
Of course, you can look better tomorrow when there is light, but the attackers will have to come in the dark and what you see is what they will see. Definitely useful information for you to have.
You are edgy of course. You aren't too worried about monsters like undead striking in the night, but that does not mean you are not worried. This is deemed the most dangerous hour for good reason. Even if the danger is not that high, it is not absent. So you find yourself looking over your shoulder at times.
But the time passes without incident, as normally happens on guard duty. After a couple of hours, you wake Ainia and allow her to be the guard while you sleep. You of course keep weapons and what armor you can put on quickly right besides your sleeping form. You remind yourself that the two of you have to shift your hours around in a random manner so any thugs will not be sure who is on guard.
All too soon, Ainia is waking you again to return to watch. And you return to boredom. However, it is not so complete boredom. Already the city is stirring, even if only barely. But some unlucky souls are stuck with jobs that must be done before business can really start, which means very early in the dark, and so the streets are no longer entirely empty. Of course one night soil collector and his cart hardly makes a traffic jam. Still, you are no longer the only thing awake.
Eventually, it is time to wake Ainia again, and to make ready for battle at an instant's notice, a battle you don't expect to happen, but still have to be ready for.
But as you thought, nothing happens expect the normal daily activities and so you can sleep in before starting a day you doubt will be entirely dull. For one thing you want to "interview" the girls. For another, you expect some action by Gilles today, tho you are unsure just what.
1113321111.title: a quiet night

11133211111.content:
Getting up and ready to face the day, you find at least some of the girls have to do some of the chores around here. A brunette nearby is struggling with a large basket of laundry. When she puts it down, two tempting hips seem to rise and attract your attention. Of course a hand of yours quickly finds a great place to rest.
The lass reacts quickly, and not favorably, until she sees you, and smiles. You think you remember her from yesterday as being very friendly. What was her name? B?...something?
"Hi" the girl grins. She turns her underclad self towards you, "I didn't get a chance to properly thank you last night, but I do want to do that as soon as I can... do it properly..." She rubs up against you. "Of course, right now I have to deal with this heavy load..."
This is an obvious invitation for you to show off your muscles, and you soon have laundry under one arm and girl under the other. The laundry is soon delivered to the proper room, and the girl to your room.
The lass slips out from your arm and urges "you must be tired from all that heavy work. Why don't you lie down?" Her removal of her limited clothing encourages your speedy obedience.
The girl climbs atop of you and straddles your body. As she gently picks at your clothing, she starts talking, "I'm Barbara in case you missed that. My parents were the poorest of the poor, and they had seven daughters who needed dowries they could not get. So I volunteered to be sold here, and now all my sisters are, or will be, honorably married because of my sacrifice. Which really isn't much of one. I am very good at making men happy, and quite enjoy my work." Her snuggling up against you seems to confirm that.
Your soldier is standing at full attention, and now Barbara lifts herself onto the tip of your staff, and carefully positions herself. Then she is sliding down your tool, to your considerable enjoyment. She leans forward, her breasts pushed invitingly in your direction. It is an invitation you quickly accept, cupping a massive mound with each hand.
As you caress her beauties, Barbara begins to move her hips, slipping up and down your piece, with both of you feeling the excitement building. Finally you can stand it no more and explode into her. She does not stop, but continues her effort to bring joy to both of you. Her own emotions are running far out of control and she is building up to a tremendous explosion, which ends with her seized by a rush of sensation so intense she collapses onto you, completely burned out. But even as she does, you shoot off again, leaving you feeling in a great mood about this lovely piece sprawled over you. You do not try to get out from under.
Instead you lie there until you hear Tabra yelling "Barbara! Where are you? Get out here and do your chores!" Barbara wakes with a start and dives for her clothing. "Sorry, I must go." she apologizes, "but if you don't feel I have thanked you enough..." But another yell from Tabra keeps her from completing the statement and she vanishes out the door at a run.
You are a little slower in getting up again, but you want to get to work. If you read the situation right, this thug will try to bribe/scare you today. So you want to be in a position where he can try that. Since you are getting a piece of the profits here, not to mention a piece of a dozen girls like Barbara, there is no chance he can offer enough, but the more you learn about your enemy, the better. So you learn the location of the most likely inn and are soon ready to go.
Of course, you are in no real rush, so maybe you can check to see if any of the other girls are properly grateful for their rescue... Or maybe...
11133211111.title: "interview" Barbara

1113322.content:
"I take girl, I keep girl?" Best to get that straight. You don't want to refuse a partnership here for just one piece of tail. Now a lass who will be there in the morning for as long as you want is quite another thing. [And best to keep up the dumb act. If they have to explain to the stupid barbarian, they can't cheat him.]
"That's right. Take whichever one will make you happy, and you will make happy. You have saved my life, but I may not be able to stay in business. If so, I will have to sell my girls, and whoever you take, I think you will be better for her than whoever might buy her.
"Like to look them over? With the mess those...gentlemen... made, we will not be open for business and they will be able to explain the advantages of owning them to you."
"Sound good. Start with blond?"
The blond is dress in an amazon outfit, or rather maybe half of one. She's tallish, if hardly in your league, and slender, tho definitely not skinny. She carries a real sword rather than some toy. She had been standing in front of the other girls trying to defend them when you barged in. [You don't think she really had much chance, but she had been trying.] As you inspect her, she stands almost at attention, and announces "I'm Ainia. I was born in Amazon territory and was on the losing side of a battle. I was eventually sold here. I serve as bouncer here when I am not serving the johns."
Her serious manner is a contrast to the next lass, who cheerfully jumps into your lap and cuddles up against you. "I'm Barbara. My parents were the poorest of the poor, and they had seven daughters who needed dowries they could not get. So I volunteered to be sold here, and now all my sisters are, or will be, honorably married because of my sacrifice. Which really isn't much of one. I am very good at making men happy, and quite enjoy my work." Her snuggling up against you seems to confirm that.
The third lass is the cleric who healed you. She's a dark brunette, but she is wearing a lot of makeup to look light, and her hair is dyed to appear blond. What little she is wearing is pure white. She bows to you respectfully. "I am Peace, a cleric of Sune, which should tell you my work here is not shameful. If not, I will be happy to tell you the teachings of Sune.
"Despite Sune not approving of slavery, I became one when I loudly and vigorously backed an idea I thought would benefit the church. I vowed I would do whatever I could to guarantee we did not lose a copper. Sadly the idea lost a good deal of gold, and I was held to my promise, and eventually ended up here as a slave. Besides my regular duties, I make sure the girls and the Johns stay healthy."
The other girls advance and introduce themselves, tho they somewhat blur together. You start considering their merits. You could use somebody to guard your flank as well as warm your bed. Ainia would be quite useful. But so would Peace. Barbarians like you get hurt a lot, and having Peace to cure you would be very nice too.
Barbara might not be so useful, but she would definitely make your life worth living, very much so. Even if you starved to death with her, you would die with a smile on your face. And each of the other girls have their own virtues. Which to choose?
Well, at least the girls are grateful for their rescue, and happy to let you have a full investigation of the merchandise.
1113322.title: companion

112.content:
The water soothed your brow. "Your name is Landeth," said the man. "You're a mercenary."

"I am? I don't remember," you said.

"I know. This is what they told me to tell you. You need to go to the Fell Doom Tavern in Greyhawk City and ask for Thumb-on-Scales."

"What? Who are you?"

"I'm Finter. I'm a marsh-jigger, I get shrimp and other things out of the marsh. I told you this yesterday, and the day before. Your three friends you'd come to eventually."

That was the first thing you remember, and that was as many days ago as you have fingers and toes. You've been recovering, and now--now you have to go, or you'll eat Finter out of his house. A lone marsh-jigger doesn't get enough food to feed a big fellow like you. If you want to learn anything of your life--if you want to earn enough to replay Finter--you need to move on.

Your hands remember, though: they remembered how to swing that sword, and how to buckle the armor and arrange the underpadding to prevent chafing. They remember the feel of the leather, the jingle of the layers of segmenta lorica, the rhythm of the long march that conserves energy while eating up distance. Finter let you off at the shore nearest this shabby road, and you've walked since. Your friends--three of them: some kind of magic user, a barbarian, a little fellow--halfling or gnome, Finter didn't know which--left some coin to pay Finter. He gave it back to you.

"I don't steal," he said. "You came with it, and you leave with it. I only did what was right."

And then he waved from his skiff, his lanky body almost gold in the dawn sunshine and any parting words swallowed by the noise of the marsh. And you're on the road to Greyhawk City. The road has grown during the day, gathered gravel and stones, lost some of the weeds that had never been stepped on.

It's almost dark. You've had nothing to eat today but some shrimp jerky and rice and weeds rolled in a leaf. Ahead of you are some lights: one is a roadside inn; the other is a house, and a rude stable outside it.
112.title: Out of the marsh

1121.content:
The door is a simple wooden affair with leather hinges and a rope holding it shut. The house is made of wood, too, sawn planks fitted together with dowels and caulked with mud. No magic was used here--but the inn across the road, he noticed, has metal hinges.

He knocks tentatively and hears the movement inside. The door opens--a young woman, who might be pretty, might not; it's hard to tell under the bruises and cuts.

"Greetings," she says, in a voice clogged with--what? fear? tears? desperation? She smooths her red-gold hair back and he notices the ears. Half-elf.

"Greetings," he says. "I come to ask leave to sleep in your shack. The manger."

She glances back into the darkness of the hut. Two rooms, maybe three. Dirt floor, rude furniture. Nothing elf-made. "You have no money for the inn?"

"I would rather not see too many people right now." People are confusing: they know who they are, and he does not.

She nods, probably thinking he is a fugitive.

"I can spare you some water, and a bit of elf-loaf, spiced with merrin."

"I can do chores."

"No!" she says quickly. "It would be obvious that I didn't. You don't need to pay me back."

"Fair is fair," he says, echoing Finter. "I'm no thief. I only want to do what is right."

She laughs. "So do I, but it's a long and difficult road to walk. Go now. To the manger. Wait there until after dark."

From across the road come the scents of smoke and wood and roasting meat, and the sounds of laughter and song. He does not know the words, but he knows the tune as he huddles unmoving in the shadows of the manger. If he doesn't move, his buckles and scale don't jingle, and he is suddenly cold, grateful for the warmth his padding gives. Night settles its aged bones.

He barely hears her padding across the grass, but he stands when she arrives. She thrusts a bit of bread and a wooden bowl of water into his hands. "You can use the privy at midnight, when all are asleep," she says.

And then she is gone with a sound like an oaken staff hitting flesh, and she tumbles to the ground. Behind where she stood is a giant of a man--gray-haired and fierce.

"I say who touches my woman and who eats my food!" he roars.
1121.title: The inhabitants of the house

11211.content:
You step backward, strong leg back, and hold up your hands in what might be a placating gesture.

"I don't want to fight you," you say, and wish you were armed and armored.

"I don't want to fight me neither," roars the big man and he swings one ham-sized fist at you. He is big and strong and your reaction is automatic. One step forward and to the side puts you away from his fist and exposes his side. One punch below the ribs, another with the other hand, and a leg sweep knocks him down; you stomp just below his rib cage. He reeks of beer.

You get your toe under his oaken staff and flip it up into your hands, and wait--that should render a normal man unconscious, but he is so big--perhaps a touch of giant blood in his ancestry?

He gets up slowly. "That was a lucky shot. Give me back my staff."

It is longer than a staff you would have cut for yourself, but it is well-balanced.

"Come and get it."

He is warier this time and the staff is long--but two of three swift raps to his ears connect. A jab to his belly has him sitting down again.

"Are you all right?" you call to the woman, but get no answer.

"I swear, if you've hurt her, you'll get worse in return," you tell the man. "Kindness begets kindness, and hurt begets hurt."

And oddly, he starts to cry--bawl like a baby, really, red-faced around the gray stubble.

"I allus knew some'un would take her. You can't hold them forever. But she was just so beautiful--"

This is not what you expected, not at all.

"I will not take her," you say, "but she is free to go, and I will enforce her decision. And you will sleep out here tonight and hope."

"And I suppose you'll be inside with your paws all over her?"

"I'll be inside, and the rest is for the woman to decide."

You gather your things and escort the lady to the hut. You listen keenly for the man, because it is when the victor is leaving that the loser often attacks again--but he sits there and cries.

The woman seems afraid of you, too, as she sits down on one of the two stools in the hut.

"And what will you do now?" she asks.
11211.title: A fight, and a woman freed

choices: to ask about the woman herself
112111.content:
"Talk." you reply quietly. "Talk, and eat, if both be acceptable to you, m'lady..." she nods, and you smile, while her bruised and battered face takes on an anxious and concerned guise. "Don't worry." you comfort her, "If he tries to come after you, I shall have to throttle him soundly, again!" She laughs a bit at your over-zealous description of the fracas in the manger, a lithe lilt of joy, which seems to catch even her off-guard.

"I... I haven't laughed in quite some time..." she confesses, her pale and dainty fingertips caressing her blue-and-purple cheek absently.

"He is a fiend!" you snap. "Like a thief, to take such beauty as yours away from this world at his own hand..." her eyes flare for a moment at your words; contempt? anger? relief?? but she sighs, her cheeks flush slightly and she shuffles meekly past you, toward a curtained-off area across the small living quarters.

"Lo'garam is no fiend..." she defends her benefactor quietly, pulling back the curtain, revealing sturdy shelves stocked with all manner of food-stuff: breads, fruits and vegetables, jugs of ale, spiced and smoked meats, all neatly arranged and organized. "He is merely outcast, a half-breed, man-beast... shunned by peers on both sides..." Like Her, you imagine without speaking, noting characteristics in her being and nature that defy classification as Human, while others defend classification as Elf. "It is not Lo'garam what has me fretting. It is that I have no food befitting a man of your stature in this humble hovel of a home..."

"My... stature?" you wonder, your mind still an empty slate when it comes to remembering your history, or recognizing anything remarkable about yourself. Maybe she knows of you? maybe this place, this village is Home to you?

"My Hero..." she turns and curtsies, that whimiscal smile ever-so-slightly crossing her lips. Together, you smile, and eventually, laugh inspite of yourselves, a 'hero' and the fair maiden. though neither of you feels at all comfortable in your roles.

Once the ice is broken, she finds comfort and some level of trust in your nature, and while she prepares a second-supper for you, her humbled guest for the evening, you may talk about whatever you wish...
112111.title: Telling Tales After Dark

choices: If you rest, recover, wake and take Krysth'Ena with you.
If you slip away before daybreak, leaving Krysth'Ena behind.
1121111.content:
Though she cannot understand what interest you might have in her history, she also cannot see any reason to keep that history secret from the man who gave her her life and future back.

"I am called Krysth'Ena... that is Old-Elvish tongue, the language of my Mother and her clan, the Ral'Mort Forest clan..." a beautiful name, you wonder what meaning it has to her, to her Mother, to her people, though her story does not quite compensate your curiosity.

"My Father was a raider, a barbarian from the foothills..." she continues. "He saved my mother and her foraging-party from certain death, a hideous and vile creature attacked from a bog in the Badlands, where elven magics failed them. In return, the Elders granted him the honor to take a bride from among the women of the clan. He chose my mother, as she had stood beside him to face the beast from the Badlands, and any elvish female strong and brave enough do that was worthy of a human barbarian husband...

Unfortunately, a female child borne of that union was not so worthy..." her face drooped, she sighed, a single tear rolling down her porcelain cheek. "My Mother was Outcast to the Elves of Ral'Mort, given the choice to accept life as the bride of a barbarian or defy the wishes of her savior, which would be the death of him as no human may be brought into the heart of Ral'Mort Forest, to the council of elves, and live to tell its secrets... she chose exile, she stood by the man who saved her lives and the lives of half-a-dozen other clan-folk... she was Outcast, as was I... this has been my lot in life, and Lo'garam found me, took me in, welcomed me, for a time... this is my lot...

"What about you, my Hero?" her tone lightens, and she smiles at you while you enjoy the stew and bread and mead she has prepared.

Your eyes are misty, expression vacant and lost in the images and heart-song of her story, and you shrug and shake your head. You cannot begin to answer her questions, to tell your tale, as your tale has only just begun.

"You know who you are, you know where you come from, yet you can never return..." you sigh, stirring your stew somberly. "I haven't a clue, myself, and I would give anything to know myself, my history, and to have your strength, to fight on through, regardless the pains of that past..."

"We are kindred spirits still..." she explained as she collected the dirty crockery and utensils from your lap while you sat on the small wooden stool. "Blank parchment, waiting to be filled with grand adventures one can barely imagine!" that spark returns to her eyes just then, that fire, that Life, and again, you smile in spite of yourself, as she inquires, "When do we begin?"

"Daybreak!" you decide with a hoist of your mug and a healthy swig of ale. "To our Destiny!" she grins and giggles, clinking her mug against yours and gulping a fair swallow of ale for herself, belching and blushing after.

You and Krysth'Ena talk well into the night, never bothered by her drunken host. Before you prepare your bedroll in the corner, you douse the single lamp in the house and glance out the small window across the yard to the manger shed. Lo'garam has passed out cold in the manger; she should be safe to sleep, and you could do with a bit more rest yourself before you get back on the trail to rediscover your legacy, your destiny, whatever the future may hold...

You're not quite certain Krysth'Ena is up to the task of leaving all that she has come to know, this life of subservience and abuse, for the life of a rootless wanderer, a renegade, outcast and enigma such as you are. You daresay it might be jsut as dangerous for her to be found in your company as it is for her to stay here in this private hell with a man-beast as her benefactor. So, the choice is left to you...
1121111.title: Herstory (as opposed to History...)

1121112.content:
This will be a great place for an interactive junction in the story!

so, if you want to ask her for more information about Lo'garam and her history with him, take that thread.

If you have another idea where to take the tale from here, choose Other, and take the story in another direction entirely.
1121112.title: Cross-Roads in the Cabin

112112.content:
"Me? I will eat this fine repast of breadcrust and stew, and sleep. I am but recently ill, and need my rest." She says nothing, but looks at you, and then at the floor. "And I will sleep on the floor, on a blanket if you have one. Your bed is yours."

"I do not want the bed. It is not mine; it was never mine. It was his."

Between bites, you watch her, even as she watches you. "Why did you stay, then?"

"Promises had been made."

You snort, then wipe your mouth. "Who can make those promises? Were you a slave?"

"Of a sort. I was happy as an elf, but I quickly outgrew my playmates. I had the body of a woman, but not the wisdom of a real woman."

"An elf woman, you mean."

Even in the darkness you can see her blush. "Yes."

"The elders sent me away. Two of the rangers of our tribe escorted me to find humans, my other family. To get what they said was my birthright."

"Perhaps they were ridding themselves of temptation."

"They would never-- They are purer than humans."

"I'm sure."

"You're mocking me."

"I'm listening to you, and thanking you for the food." You stand and stretch. "If you do not want the bed, I will take it. I have long leagues to travel, and I will take the comfort of a straw tick whenever I can."

"Where are you going?"

"Greyhawk city."

"I can sing some small enchantments. I could be of use."

"You are a constant temptation to those I meet. You are beautiful, and they will want you."

"You will protect me?"

You sigh. It is madness to make a promise like this so soon, when you know so little of the road ahead.

"I will," you say. "I will keep you from harm."

Rather than gladdening her, your words bring an oblique sadness to her face. She does not say anything more, so you blow out the candle and pull the quilt around you.

She settles down at the foot of the bed. Just at the edge of sleep, you hear her say, "He promised the same thing."
112112.title: A midnight talk

1121121.content:
After a restless sleep you eat the gruel breakfast she provides and you head out the door. She pauses, and you expect her to tie the door shut--but she doesn't. She says, "He is waiting, and watching." You cannot spot him. She throws open her arms and says, "I return to you this shelter I have borrowed."

You think, Now everyone knows we're here, and leaving.

Of course, there's no reason why they shouldn't know, is there?

You cannot remember if you asked her name, or if she told you and you forgot, or if she never told you. No matter; there will be time on the road to ask.

You walk until the sun is high and then pause at a fork in the road. Signs for both roads point to Greyhawk. You look at her.

"One road leads up, into hills, through lands that do not feed travelers; the other leads lower, through the last neck of the marsh. I have overheard tavern talk that the marsh road is cursed; that those who walk it alone do not always make it through."

"We don't have provisions to take the high road," you point out.

"True. But we are not equipped to fight a curse."
1121121.title: A restless start

11212.content:
Best to talk your way out of this. You put both hands up, open, as if to keep him away; those hands will push away punches, you hope.

"Just a moment. There's no need--"

A fist comes flying, and you manage to push it aside. The man falls over from the force of his punch, and you take the opportunity to take his lamp. Can't hit what you can't see, you reason, but lamps are harder to put out than you thought--you can't see the lever to raise the glass.

And suddenly, the man is kneeling before you, penitent.

"I didden know, Your Majesty. I didden know."

Rather than ask him what he didn't know, you run, letting the sound of your boots on the roadway guide you. In ten minutes the house is out of sight, and you stop, panting, hoping the man hasn't followed.

It will be a cold night sleeping on the ground, but you are sooo tired...

There is a sound behind you. It might be him, or it might be something worse.
11212.title: The surprising incident of the man

1122.content:
The smells of smoke and roasted meat and drying vegetables, of fish and sour ale, of unwashed people hit his nostrils and he gagged for just a moment, then stepped into the gloom. Why should it bother him when this morning he had been in the sulfurous stink of the marsh?

No reason he could fathom.

There were almost two hands worth of people there, none armored, none armed, mostly human men holding horns and sitting on the floor around the firepit. A spit held three times as many squab roasting there. A burly woman moved among them, refilling horns with her alegoose.

"Sir?" said a thickset man in tunic and hose. He had a way of dragging out the i so it was halfway between sir and sire. "Your sword? We don't want no trouble."

"Of course." He was reluctant to give up his sword. "Do you have peacewire?"

"Never heard of it."

"Oh." He drew his sword slowly, careful not to cause alarm, and handed it, hilt first, to the thick man. Once he had, everyone drooped as though they had been expecting--

Something. What, he wasn't sure.

"Ale, sir?" said the woman. She had the same accent. She leaned in. "Nobody purifies our water, so you're best to take the ale."

He nodded, and she handed him a drinking horn. He mumbled his thanks.

The ale was sour and bitter and quenched his thirst. They watched him drain the horn and then he looked back--and they began to talk among themselves.

"Food, sire?" He was sure he heard it as sire. He shook his head to clear it, then waved her back.

"I'll have some. Fine."

One of the men, young and fox-like, came over to him. "So what are you calling yourself?"

"My name is Landeth."

"I'm Perd." He squatted easily beside him. "So whatcha travelling for?"
1122.title: Food, drink, and gossip

11221.content:
"Traveling." He briefly considered telling Perd the truth, but he didn't know this man, didn't know any of them. "A pilgrimage."

"Any god in particular?"

"I'm under a vow not to talk about it."

"But you can claim you're a pilgrim?"

Landeth nodded.

"And if I guess right, can you let me know?"

Landeth grinned. "No."

"And I was looking for a game of Questions." He frowned good-naturedly.

The burly woman brought him a loaf of dark bread with the center scooped out to make a bowl. "Here you go, sire."

"Sir," he said. "I'm not your sire."

"You're not old enough for one thing," said Perd. She looked scandalized, then punched Perd in the shoulder.

"Sorry, sir." She bent down to pick up an alegoose that had fallen from her apron when she punched Perd, and began to polish it with her apron. "Your secret's safe here, sir."

"Of course," Landeth said, without knowing what she meant.

"Perd!" called one of the other men. "Your turn. What's your story?"

Perd rolled his eyes. "Be back later."

"Don't hurry on my account," said Landeth.
11221.title: A Mysterious Conversation

112211.content:
You sit down by yourself on the opposite wall of the fire pit watching the men drink and tell stories, not far to the right of you notice a rather loud group of men and one dwarf playing some game resembling liars dice

The shouts of the sastified dwarf as he gloats of his winnings mingles with the plucking of a nearby minstrel carefully picking a tune on his mandolin.
It is then, that you spot the figure,
Amongst all the chatter and and clanging from the kitchen you see in the opposite corner of the inn a cloaked figure sitting alone, with a his head turned to you.

His outline barely illuminated by the light from the flickering fire, yet his face is shrouded by the hood pulled tightly over his head.
This stranger makes you uneasy for after a while of trying to ignore him to soon realise his attention is set on you,

Perhaps you should approach him, and ask as to why he is staring at you
Or you could just wait a while longer and maybe he will lose interest.
112211.title: A mysterious stranger

choices: A heavily armored man enters the inn
1122112.content:
You try and forget about the odd figure and instead try to remember what has happened to you in the past few days. You can't remember much about yourself but find something truly odd that your supposide companions would leave you there in the marsh.

Just then Perd returns, and casually takes the seat across from you.

"So where did you run off to?" you ask him
"Oh nowhere, don't worry about it," he replies, his eyes flicking from you to the kitchen door nervously

"Perd," you say with an obvious aire of curiosity in your voice.
"Who is that across the room there, the odd one in the cloak?"
Perd looks over to him, his face expressionless.
"Why, has he said something to you?" Perd asks with a surprised tone.
"Well, no he just been sitting over there, just staring at me".

"Well i'm not really sure all i know is that he is here every night but never says a word to anyone." Perd answers

Just then......
1122112.title: Ignore him

choices: You seduce the girl [or try to anyway]
11221121.content:
Perhaps your words are a little louder than you think. Perhaps it is something else. In any case, the mysterious figure in the cloak now stands and approaches. He pauses at the edge of your table and asks, "You are aware of the mysterious stranger who shows up to offer you ways to glory and riches?"
"That's just a cliche!" Perd objects, "A bad one too."
"Cliches become so because they are true and common.", the figure briefly looks at Perd before returning his? gaze? to you. [The light in here is poor, but really, you ought to be able to see more detail than you are.] "...as you would know from your past. I am such a figure, and I can, with luck, lead you to fame and fortune."
"You know of my past?", you ask, more interested in recovering your memories than in the wild ravings of riches. [Somehow you 'remember' there have been several past cases where the fame was fleeting at most, and the fortune vanished just as fast.]
"Sadly, no." admits the figure as he sits down, "I only know what you are, not what you were."
"And what is that?" you continue.
"You are a toy of Chance in its game with Fate." he starts to lecture, "While the life of most of those present will follow a path set by Fate, you have the power to change that, or not change it. In a way that even the wise can only begin to understand, you have been freed of whatever doom was upon you, and you are now a wild card, able to change the game, perhaps in great degree."
"I am just a fighter." you protest, "I may be pretty good, but there are better, and I am nobody special. How am I supposed to change the world?"
"That, I can only guess at." the mysterious one admits, "When Chance takes a hand, all is uncertain. Perhaps you will found a great empire. Perhaps you will merely kill the one who was going to found that empire. Perhaps your freed actions will merely get you killed, and you will never found that empire. I just do not know, and there is no way to know, even if we were of the gods.
"What I do know," he continues, "...is that a decision or decisions you will be making, perhaps very soon, will have a massive influence, even if nobody, yourself included, deems it of any importance and all forget it ever happened.
"And I know that Fortune favors the brave." he adds in a more heated voice, "I can assure you of nothing, but if you follow my guidance and take the bold path, the possibilities are endless."
"Sounds great!" Perd enthuses, "Let's do it!"
"Has this crazy old man been bothering you?" the barmaid asks as she refills your horn. Now that you think about it, this is not the first refill either. Possibly this is why you decide that 'burly' is not the proper description for her. That figure may have heft to it, but it is still a fine figure, and you have always preferred lasses you didn't have to worry would break in half when you gave them a good squeeze. [You have? Is this your memory starting to come back? Well, it seems right anyway.]
"Hmm... So you are saying that if I am bold with this lovely lass here, I may father the next emperor?" you 'ask' the old? man, "It seems a most desirable task."
"You try that, and I'll box your ears!", the lass retorts. "I'm no man's idle plaything to be discarded after a night."
Actually, she probably is, at least for the right price, and as little coin as you have, you know it is enough to pay for several barmaids. Of course, you will likely have to approach her in the right way. Slap the gold on the table and she is apt to get all huffy and refuse, or demand double. But if you say the right words, and merely hint about your excess coin... Well, your bed may be delightfully crowded tonight.
"That is not what I mean at all!", your would-be adviser crossly disputes, "Granted, it could happen, but the odds are..."
But you are no longer listening. The charms of the lass are much more enticing. Of course, it is a long trip to Greyhawk and you may need your coin. So maybe it is foolish to be spending it on the first woman you see. Still...
11221121.title: The cloaked figure approaches you

11221122.content:
The door to the inn swings violently open. Standing there in the doorway is a large rough looking man, with a thick mustache and a scraggly beard slightly discolored.He wears a great deal of armor with a breatplate, pauldrons, chainmals leggings, and heavy studded bracers, with a black and green tunic thrown over it.

He walks in proudly with his heavy boots thudding loudly on the floor. When the man at the door asks for his weapons, this necomer pushes him to the side and says....

"And who are you to tell me that i can't keep my weapon, i think you of all people should know that such a upsurd comment can lead to some unfortunate things." the burly man complains. Most people in the inn don't seem to notice but you can tell that this man means trouble. When you look back over to Perd he has a look of panic on his face, he quickly stands up and turns to the kitchen.

"Whats wrong, now were are you going," you ask Perd.

He doesn't answer and quickly go out to the back. You look over to the cloaked figure and notice that his attention is now on this new man.
The burly looking beast of a man sat down at the counter and yelled for an pint of mead. The cloaked figure stood up and walked to the door, just before he walks out he takes one last look at you and slams the door behind him.

When you turn your head back to the armored man you see him standing not far from you looking at you with a suspicious look on his face.

"Do I know you?" he asks you in his gruff voice

"Where you ever a recruit for the Greyhawk Gaurd force?" he asks

"Well i can't .." and just as you start to answer him he interrupts and says "Wait i have seen you before your one of those mercenaries from Fogwood" he yells

And then without warning he grabs you out of you chair and an tavern brawl errupts.
11221122.title: A heavily armored man enters the inn

choices: Sneak out when Perd sleeps, for he means harm
11222.content:
(Oh, well. I put the actual text for this one under the other entry--so let's swap. Even though the links say otherwise, this is the entry for telling Perd about Greyhawk city.)

Something about Perd's manner inspires you to trust him--or perhaps it's some form of desperation. If you don't know anyone, you must trust someone sometime.

Briefly, you lay out for Perd your circumstances as you know them. You have no memory, you must get to Greyhawk, and you're looking for a particular tavern. You had three companions.

Perd looks at you. "You don't know who you are?" he says quietly.

"No."

"Keep your voice down."

"Certainly."

"Let's go to the jakes."

You had joined the afternoon exercises, the evening prayer and the occult teachings later. Finally you had entered the tiny room where you laid yourself to rest. But you arose with a disturbance felt and sensed, a violation of the spiritual equilibrium which you knew as normalcy within the monastery walls.

The smell of bloodshed was in the air, the sounds of skirmishes all around you. Other novices and disciples on their way to leave the building and find out what was going on already.

Looking around you see that one of the Abbot's guards, fellow monks and nuns just doing duty, has been killed by crossbow bolts. Two others are pinned by the Luskan snipers, who lay low on the roof of the library.

Without hesitation you jump-start into a run. Closing the distance to the edge of the novice building's rooftop, deflecting the craven shot by a sniper much as expected, you leap upon the roof of the library!

While the two Luskan snipers clearly see you coming, your valiant initiative has allowed your fellow monks to improve their own position.

One crossbow bolt misses you by a narrow margin, but one shot hits your side, punching a bloody wound into your right side of the torso.

You must act fast now, as you cannot afford to wait, until the guards neutralize the snipers. Decide for your preferred way of attack versus these two snipers and hope for the best...

As a bard, you make your living playing music, singing songs, and generally keeping folks' spirits up. Greyhawke is a sprawling city, ruled by thieves and terrorized by roaming marauders from across the lands; civilian-types make a pittance farming the outskirts, or crafting and selling their wares in city squares peppering each quarter, but much of the profits are claimed by the guilds, leaving the general populace near-squalor. Greyhawke probably wouldn't have developed into the urban populace of today but for the security offered by its massive outer walls and battlements, as well as a fine naval fleet which patrols and defends the harbor. Peasants who tire of the greedy looting and pillaging of their hard-earned wares and profits quickly come scampering back under the protective blanket of the Guilds whenever ogres enclaves or goblin hoardes make way from the foothills and sweep a swath of terror across the plains.

Your job at the Black Dragon Inn is to keep the minds of the travelling merchants off their troubles with epic odes of bountiful harvest, to inspire the local troops with songs of bravery and hard-fought battles, and to act as the eyes and ears of the Guilds around folks who do not place trust or faith in the guild ways of rule. Your calm and pleasant demeanor, soft but well-spoken words, and fanciful instrumentals and singing voice have served you well, and garnered much respect, praise, and a tidy profit from the meager and haggard patrons of the Black Dragon. And your connection to the Guilds helps insure that your cut of profit stays well within reason, compared to Outsiders and local-though-unaffiliated traders and craftsmen.

But if I have to do some favor for him? All sorts of ways that can turn out badly for me. And he may well be offering to pay me by not killing me. Not that I am going to turn an offer like that down, but...
But now he is back, his hands full of a mess of objects which he lays down with a clatter. "To start with, I have this little gift for you, which I am sure you will love. In fact I am sure you won't be parted from it." He somehow is placing a ring on my finger despite my fingers being clenched. No way to know what that ring does, but I'm betting I can't take it off, and that he can find me any time he wants to, which means that taking whatever suicide job he is about to suggest, and then just running away, is likely suicidal too.

"So would you like to learn more about me? Or would you prefer to tell me about yourself?"

He possesses all three types of magical spells in near equal quantities, e.g. offensive, defensive and informational types of magic. These are tucked away in various places so as not to be obvious to a casual inspection. He wears a ring of free action on his right hand and a ring of water-breathing on his left. This only applies if the rest of the group decides to have the member brought back from the dead.

Pelias can work with any other type of human or non-human class. He does not have a problem working with thieves as long as they do not attempt to work their trade against or on him. 1342221.content:
Pelias walked from his inn just off the main square heading for the large board of announcements and notices near the well in the center of town. He quickly but carefully looked over the notices, seeing two which might be of interest. A third notice was more interesting, but it was almost four months old. Such notices usually indicated the party had either moved on or had already left and had not returned.

As he turned back to the board, a crier entered the square. "Hear ye! Hear ye! The DuMas party, consisting of seven, seeks the services of another priest, a mage, a rouge, cook and horse handler. Anyone so interested may seek them in The Hunter's Call today or tomorrow after the hour of noon and before the hour of dinner. The party will be leaving on the morning of the third day. Anyone following will be considered thieves and punished accordingly!"

Pelias grinned to himself. Some caravan masters liked to follow adventuring groups out of towns to have help if bandits tried attacking. Since this put the adventurers in the middle for no gain and usually much loss, the groups were usually very unhappy to have a caravan leaving around the time they were. It seemed the leader of this group had perhaps found a way to deter this practice...

Since he still had some time before noon, he went back to the board to obtain more details of other offers.

13422212.content:
Pelias took several minutes reading the three notices which had most caught his eye. While he could not recall every detail of everything he had ever read or seen, he could remember most of them. It was one of the things which helped make him a valuable member of any group with which he went out. He moved out toward The Lusty Lady. It was an inn near the south gates of the city. It had seen better days, but still was in decent repair with big rooms for large parties. He entered the darkened area, pausing to let his eyes adjust before moving to the desk. "Are there any members of the Sen party still around?" he asked. (He pronounced Sen as Sawn.)

"As a matter of fact, there's the man himself just coming down the stairs." The clerk raised both head and voice, calling, "Hey Sen, there's a man here to see you." Pelias had turned to see the man, stocky with dark hair and eyes, wearing a traveling cloak and a short sword change direction to head toward the desk.

"Thanks," Pelias said as he flipped a silver penny to the clerk. "Saw your notice on the board this morning."

"Notice?" Sen asked, looking puzzled. "I haven't posted any notice in at least three months.

"Yes, the notice was dated almost four months ago."

"Well, my group has finished the adventure which that notice addressed. We're planning on taking a month off to recover and recuperate before we go back again. We will be looking for additional men. We lost four men out of twenty taken with five more injured badly. In time, they should all recover. Of the four killed, one was a priest; two were rogues and the last was a swordsman. Three of four mages were among the injured along with two more swordsmen. We arrived back in town last night and the injured are already being treated in the temple."

"Will you be posting another notice before you leave again?" Pelias asked, thinking fast about what had been said as well as what hadn't. Nothing had been said about the dead being revived, so Pelias had a good idea they were still dead. He still hadn't heard anything mentioned about either the treasure or what it had been which had beat up the group so badly. But, anything which could take out a third of such a powerful group was something which needed respected.

"Yes, the notice will go up in about two weeks." He'd noticed the shooting guard around Pelias' left arm and the stiffness under of the mail under the robes Pelias wore. "A good archer can earn an extra half share of treasure."

"I'll keep it in mind," Pelias answered. What he really desired right now was to speak to the survivors. He bowed to Sen before leaving.

134222122.content:
Pelias walked slowly back to the square, thinking about what he'd learned. Nothing had been mentioned about where the injured from the party were being treated. From that, he concluded questioning the survivors would be frowned upon. The more he thought about what he still didn't know, the more his gut was telling him to stay clear of this group. Everything might just point to the members of the Sen party being cautious about loosing a source of income, but this was being cautious to the extreme.

He arrived back at the square just after the hour of noon and proceeded to walk to The Hunter's Call. A large table sat off to one side of the entrance with four men seated at it. Each of the men had a goblet sitting before them. There were four chairs sitting, one across from each man, on the opposite side of the table. Three of the chairs were occupied. Pelias walked over to the table and stood by the open chair. The man sitting across from this chair looked up at him. "Have you come to apply for a position with the DuMas Party?"

"I have."

"Please then, be seated. I am Thomas DuMas. What position do you seek to fill?"

Pelias sat, then answered, "By profession, I am a mage. As you can see, I am also a Half-Elf. I can shoot a longbow and have some modest ability with a short sword and dagger. While I make no claims to ability, I also eat what I cook and have not died from it yet."

The man laughed, "Splendid! It is good to meet a mage with a sense of humor. While I can make no promises as to additional shares for your extra skills, it is possible that when the treasure is divided afterward, some additional consideration may come your way. If you are selected and should you agree to join us, know that we pledge to do all in our power to keep you alive should you be injured. Alas, we have not the funds nor do we expect to obtain sufficient treasure from this adventure to pay for resurrection should you fall. If you supply us with the necessary information, a full share of the gains will be delivered to your next-of-kin should this happen. Food and basic supplies will be provided. We require you supply your own mount and weapons. As a mage, your earnings will be one and one-quarter shares. This is expected to cover the extra costs of your spell components. Should you feel this is not sufficient, you may argue your case with us if we agree to hire your services. If there is nothing else, please leave your name and where you are staying so we may contact you should we choose you."

"My name is Pelias and I have taken lodging in this Inn."

"Very well. We will contact you no later than the dinner hour tomorrow should we choose you."

Pelias stood, gave a half bow and replied, "Thank you for your time."

An hour after dinner, there was a knock at Pelias' door. He opened it to see Thomas DuMas and the three other men from earlier standing there. "Please enter. I would offer wine, but I fear I do not have enough goblets for all."

Another man spoke, "Do not worry about that. I am Reynold DuMas, the leader of this group. You have already met Thomas. This is James," he said, indicating one man, "and Pieter. We are brothers. One day, very early in the morning, Ollie set out to catch some fish in the nearby river. He had a spot, near a rocky overhang where the fat lazy fish liked to pool in the morning before the sun heated the water there. When he was in luck, he usually managed to catch three or sometimes four of them. And, sometimes, they managed to take all his bait no matter what tricks he tried. Today, he was in luck, catching four big sunfish almost as soon as he threw his line into the water.

As Ollie was getting ready to head back home, something broke a branch behind him and he froze, tucking himself into a small crevice at the edge of the overhang. Above him, he heard two voices talking in a guttural tone. He had never heard this language before, but hearing it now sent chills down his spine. He stayed put while the voices continued...

(Spoken in Orcish and translated into common here,) "I'm telling you, I heard something over here. It has to be one of those humans from that village we're gonna attack later."

"You're full of it! I think you're just scared and want to go running back home to your momma and this is your way of doin it... OHhh! The big bad humans are gonna get me, Ohhh!"

(Back to our story.) For whatever reason, there was much grunting and shouting from above him and suddenly, a heavy body fell over the edge of the outcropping and into the water, slowly staining it red. Ollie looked at the creature who looked back at him. It gave him a grimace-like smile before its eyes closed forever. From above him, Ollie heard something else being shouted down at the other which he couldn't understand. "You always were a lousy fighter. You should a been a female!" Then, there were the sounds of something moving off and after a bit, there was silence.

Ollie looked at the fish hanging from his line in one hand and the body in the water before him. He sighed and set the fish down. Concentrating, he gathered the mystical energy around him and cast his spell. The body lifted out of the water and floated before him in the air. Ollie grabbed his fish and headed for home, pushing the floating body before him. By the time he was halfway home, he was sweating as if he'd ran fifty miles. This was the hardest thing he'd ever done in his life! By the time he had covered another quarter of the way, he was shaking hard and stumbling over everything in his path.

Fortunately, one of his friends, Otak, the smith, had just stepped out side to see to some work on a plow. He saw Ollie stumble, then stumble again. Whatever he had been pushing before him crashed to the ground and Otak saw him fall on top of it. "Sven, Thomas" he called. Sven stepped outside to see what was going on. He was in his final year of apprenticeship to Otak and was almost as heavily muscled as the older man. Thomas was in his first year of apprenticeship and did much of the minor, but extremely important jobs which had made the smithy a solid reputation as a teacher. "Sven, you come with me. Ollie collapsed in the field. He was coming toward the village, pushing something which I think may have been a body. Thomas, you go and roust the mayor out of his comfortable seat in the Inn. Tell him I said it is necessary. Don't tarry. And, if he tries to ignore you, tell him I have instructed you to to the shire next. And, actually, now that I think on it, do that, whether he the mayor comes or not. Go!" he commanded. Thomas took off at a run. "Sven, I doubt we need them, but..." Otak let his voice trail off and Sven stepped back into the smithy and returned moments later with two maces and two daggers. Each man took one of each weapon and headed out to where the boy had fallen.

Otak looked at the body Ollie had brought with him and spat, "Orc!"

Sven was scanning the countryside, "I don't see any of them. That could be good or bad."

Otak grunted a chuckle and picked up Ollie. His breathing was weak and he lolled lifelessly in the big smithy's hands. His clothes were drenched in sweat. Otak had smelled the sour stench of it as he checked out the boy earlier. The four fish he had caught fell to the ground beside him. "All right lad, let's see what we can see. You were out fishin for breakfast and caught yerself four nice uns. Then, this orc fell into yer path. Yer felt it important enough t' see we knew what yu'd found, sos yer brought it back with yer. Now, yer wouldn't a been a killin yerself iffin yer hadn't been worried bout somtin, and since thin un died by a sword stroke through the gut, I'm being to guessin theres more of them orcs and theys fixin to pay us a visit, mos likely round bout dinner time. How's I doin so far lad?" he asked the unconscious boy.

The shire, a man of early middle age grunted, "Well, I ain't been called a lad in many a year now, Otak, but I'd be sayin yer got the right of hit. How be the lad? Will he make it?"

He used himself up tryin to bring us warning. If he a hadn't, we'd a laughed ourselves silly, much to our dismay later. I'd be sayin he deserves a heroes reward fer savin our hides. Course now, the hardest part's the waitin..."

The shire and the smith spread the word around and within a few hours, everyone was heading into the town. Ollie was placed in a room at the Inn where he could rest and the town healer came to see him. After lookin the boy over, he went back to the common room and had a draft of ale. "The lad will live. As for his magicin abilities, won't know about them until later on. But, its sure to be one a two things what happens to them. Either he's burnt hisself out or he'll be stronger for whut he's done. But, till he tries to do magic, we won't know fer sure."

Pretty Mary Markwood, the innkeeper's middle aged daughter, was a full year older than Ollie. She'd always sort of liked him, but he was so far below her status, that any thought of marriage was out of the question. She was listening to the town elders talking about the upcoming attack. Her father had put Ollie into a small room, near the back of the Inn and over the kitchen, so getting any rest there was questionable. The only reason he'd done so at all was because the rest of the elders had insisted. She had also overheard the healer's report and shrank back, her fist crammed into her mouth to prevent any outcry on her part. She sneaked back into Ollie's room and bathed his hot head with cool water. "Ollie?" she asked in a low voice. "Ollie, can you hear me?"

Ollie moaned and opened his eyes. "M-Ma-" he choked out. She poured him a glass of water, holding it when she saw how shaky his hands were. After Ollie had drank the better part of two glasses, he sat up slowly. His head spun, but his voice was steadier this time, "Mary! Wha?"

She shushed him by putting her hand over his mouth. "I overheard father and the others talking in the common room. The shire sent a rider for aid, but no one thinks help will arrive in time. Please, will you stay with me?" She blushed, making her even prettier in Ollie's eyes. She looked down lest he think her too bold.

Ollie reached out and raised her head. "Don't ever look down around me, Mary. You're one of the few people who have ever thought I would make something of myself. You have nothing to be ashamed of around me, although, "he went on, musingly, "if someone caught us in this position..."

The door opened and Mary jumped almost out of her skin. Framed in the doorway, Otak grinned, "I see yer be doin as a bit of alright, then?"

"Let me past!" snapped her fathers voice. Otak stepped into the small room, guiding Mary behind him so her father wouldn't see her. As Stephan Markwood strode into the room, several of the elders followed him inside. "I see you've awakened, no doubt you wish to remain here, stinking up my Inn and living off your new status if this attack happens as predicted."

Otak hustled the girl out of the room as he said, "Enon a that, Stephan. We'll be seein soon enon if what we think will happen will be a happenin. Can yer tell us aboot this mornin lad," the big man asked gently.

I waited until I hadn't heard anything fer a while, then I headed back to town as fast as I could. I thought I saw you afore I collapsed, but by then, I wasn't sure a much as to real or not."

Ollie started to follow the man, then hesitated, "I can't go. I have to find Mary and Katy."

The man looked impatient, but said, "Hurry then. The orcs in the other room are dead, but there are still plenty of live ones around."

Ollie nodded his understanding, then bolted from the room and down a flight of concealed stairs into a cool stone room where Stephan Markwood kept his casks of ale, barrels of apples and potatoes and anything else needing to stay cold stored. "Mary! Katy! Are you down here? Tis Ollie! We need to flee to another place lest we be trapped."

Both girls peered from behind some barrels. Katy had been crying, but was silent for the time being. Mary looked scared. She had heard the tales of what orcs did to human females they captured, but she managed a smile for Ollie. "I knew you'd protect me - us," she corrected, looking at Katy. "Where are we going?"

"I'm not sure, but there is a man upstairs waiting for us. We need to hurry."

"What if he's a slaver?" Mary asked.

Ollie hesitated. He hadn't thought of that possibility. "If he is, then he'll be sorry he messed with you two. I'll make sure of it!"

"How about you, Ollie? How are you doing?"

"I'm fine, Mary. I feel really good." And, to Ollie's amazement, he really did feel good. The drained feeling he had had earlier was gone. True, he felt as if he could eat a whole cow by himself, but otherwise, he felt really, really good. "Let's go then. Katy, you've been really brave. But we need you to be even braver for a while. You can't scream or cry until we're safe. You understand?" Katy, her eyes big, nodded. "Mary, you take her hand. I'll need my hands free in case I have to do more magic."

His stomach rumbled and Mary said, "Wait a moment." She ran over and pulled three apples from one barrel and two potatoes from another. She also pulled down a strip of jerked meat and handed all but two apples to him. "You're going to need something to eat if you're going to keep using magic. Otherwise, you'll fall out in a faint and won't be able to protect us. Katy and I will be fine with an apple apiece until after the fight is over." Ollie had taken the food from Mary and was almost finished with it by the time she had finished talking. He hadn't realized just how famished he had been. Mary frowned, then went back to the barrels and took out three more potatoes and another apple. She handed them to Ollie and said, "Let's go."

By the time they reached the top of the stairs, Ollie had finished everything but the jerky. And, it was over half gone! He listened for a moment before opening the door and leading the girls out. The man who had offered him shelter was fighting an orc. The orc had a short sword while the man had a stout cudgel. The orc had his back to Ollie. He motioned for the girls to stay still and he moved quietly behind the orc. When he was just out of range of the sword, he threw a chair at the orcs legs, yelling at the same time. The orc started to turn around at the same moment the chair hit him. He fell heavily and before he could recover, the man had smashed his skull with his club. "Good job," he panted, "Let's go!"

Ollie picked up the sword. He had never used a weapon like this before, but had no intention of leaving it for another orc to find and use. They left the In, darting across the street and into a house there. The door opened just before they reached it so they could get inside without slowing. Ollie looked around to see half of the town's womenfolk, armed with cleavers and staffs, in the room. "Best be off to help with the clean-up," one stern looking woman with steel gray hair said to the man. He bobbed his head and left without a word. Ollie was about to say he should be out fighting, too when he saw his mother, his two younger brothers and all three of his sisters standing near a corner of the room.

"You've done enough for today," his mother said kindly, her pride in her son clear in both voice and eyes.
